trans-unit.source: How to use Azure Search from a .NET Application | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Azure Search from a .NET Application | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to use Azure Search from a .NET Application
trans-unit.target: How to use Azure Search from a .NET Application

trans-unit.source: How to use Azure Search from a .NET Application
trans-unit.target: How to use Azure Search from a .NET Application

trans-unit.source: This article is a walkthrough to get you up and running with the <link><linkText>Azure Search .NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This article is a walkthrough to get you up and running with the <link><linkText>Azure Search .NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can use the .NET SDK to implement a rich search experience in your application using Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: You can use the .NET SDK to implement a rich search experience in your application using Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: What's in the Azure Search SDK
trans-unit.target: What's in the Azure Search SDK

trans-unit.source: The SDK consists of a client library, Microsoft.Azure.Search.
trans-unit.target: The SDK consists of a client library, Microsoft.Azure.Search.

trans-unit.source: It enables you to manage your indexes, data sources, and indexers, as well as upload and manage documents, and execute queries, all without having to deal with the details of HTTP and JSON.
trans-unit.target: It enables you to manage your indexes, data sources, and indexers, as well as upload and manage documents, and execute queries, all without having to deal with the details of HTTP and JSON.

trans-unit.source: The client library defines classes like Index, Field, and Document, as well as operations like Indexes.Create and Documents.Search on the SearchServiceClient and SearchIndexClient classes.
trans-unit.target: The client library defines classes like Index, Field, and Document, as well as operations like Indexes.Create and Documents.Search on the SearchServiceClient and SearchIndexClient classes.

trans-unit.source: These classes are organized into the following namespaces:
trans-unit.target: These classes are organized into the following namespaces:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Search</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Search</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: The current version of the Azure Search .NET SDK is a pre-release version.
trans-unit.target: The current version of the Azure Search .NET SDK is a pre-release version.

trans-unit.source: If you would like to provide feedback for us to incorporate in the first stable version, please visit our <link><linkText>feedback page</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you would like to provide feedback for us to incorporate in the first stable version, please visit our <link><linkText>feedback page</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The .NET SDK supports version 2015-02-28 of the Azure Search REST API, documented on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: The .NET SDK supports version 2015-02-28 of the Azure Search REST API, documented on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: New features that are not part of this version, such as support for Microsoft's natural language processors or the moreLikeThis search parameter, are in preview and not yet available in the SDK.
trans-unit.target: New features that are not part of this version, such as support for Microsoft's natural language processors or the moreLikeThis search parameter, are in preview and not yet available in the SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can check back on <link><linkText>Search service versioning</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Latest updates to Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link> for status updates on either feature.
trans-unit.target: You can check back on <link><linkText>Search service versioning</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Latest updates to Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link> for status updates on either feature.

trans-unit.source: Other features not supported in this SDK include:
trans-unit.target: Other features not supported in this SDK include:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Management Operations</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Management Operations</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Management operations include provisioning Azure Search services and managing API keys.
trans-unit.target: Management operations include provisioning Azure Search services and managing API keys.

trans-unit.source: These will be supported in a separate Azure Search .NET Management SDK in the future.
trans-unit.target: These will be supported in a separate Azure Search .NET Management SDK in the future.

trans-unit.source: Requirements for the SDK
trans-unit.target: Requirements for the SDK

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 or a newer version.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 or a newer version.

trans-unit.source: Your own Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: Your own Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: In order to use the SDK, you will need the name of your service and one or more API keys.
trans-unit.target: In order to use the SDK, you will need the name of your service and one or more API keys.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create a service in the portal</linkText><title></title></link> will help you through these steps.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create a service in the portal</linkText><title></title></link> will help you through these steps.

trans-unit.source: Download the Azure Search .NET SDK <link><linkText>NuGet package</linkText><title></title></link> by using "Manage NuGet Packages" in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Download the Azure Search .NET SDK <link><linkText>NuGet package</linkText><title></title></link> by using "Manage NuGet Packages" in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Just search for the package name Microsoft.Azure.Search on NuGet.org.
trans-unit.target: Just search for the package name Microsoft.Azure.Search on NuGet.org.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to select "Include Prerelease" to ensure that the pre-release SDK will appear in the search results.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to select "Include Prerelease" to ensure that the pre-release SDK will appear in the search results.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search .NET SDK supports applications targeting the .NET Framework 4.0 or higher, as well as Windows Store apps targeting Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search .NET SDK supports applications targeting the .NET Framework 4.0 or higher, as well as Windows Store apps targeting Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1.

trans-unit.source: Silverlight is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Silverlight is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Core Scenarios
trans-unit.target: Core Scenarios

trans-unit.source: There are several things you'll need to do in your search application.
trans-unit.target: There are several things you'll need to do in your search application.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll cover these core scenarios:
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll cover these core scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Creating an index
trans-unit.target: Creating an index

trans-unit.source: Populating the index with documents
trans-unit.target: Populating the index with documents

trans-unit.source: Searching for documents using full-text search and filters
trans-unit.target: Searching for documents using full-text search and filters

trans-unit.source: The sample code that follows illustrates each of these.
trans-unit.target: The sample code that follows illustrates each of these.

trans-unit.source: Feel free to use the code snippets in your own application.
trans-unit.target: Feel free to use the code snippets in your own application.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: The sample application we'll be exploring creates a new index named "hotels", populates it with a few documents, then executes some search queries.
trans-unit.target: The sample application we'll be exploring creates a new index named "hotels", populates it with a few documents, then executes some search queries.

trans-unit.source: Here is the main program, showing the overall flow:
trans-unit.target: Here is the main program, showing the overall flow:

trans-unit.source: We'll walk through this step by step.
trans-unit.target: We'll walk through this step by step.

trans-unit.source: First we need to create a new SearchServiceClient.
trans-unit.target: First we need to create a new SearchServiceClient.

trans-unit.source: This object allows you to manage indexes.
trans-unit.target: This object allows you to manage indexes.

trans-unit.source: In order to construct one, you need to provide your Azure Search service name as well as an admin API key.
trans-unit.target: In order to construct one, you need to provide your Azure Search service name as well as an admin API key.

trans-unit.source: If you provide an incorrect key (for example, a query key where an admin key was required), the SearchServiceClient will throw a CloudException with the error message "Forbidden" the first time you call an operation method on it, such as Indexes.Create.
trans-unit.target: If you provide an incorrect key (for example, a query key where an admin key was required), the SearchServiceClient will throw a CloudException with the error message "Forbidden" the first time you call an operation method on it, such as Indexes.Create.

trans-unit.source: If this happens to you, double-check our API key.
trans-unit.target: If this happens to you, double-check our API key.

trans-unit.source: The next few lines call methods to create an index named "hotels", deleting it first if it already exists.
trans-unit.target: The next few lines call methods to create an index named "hotels", deleting it first if it already exists.

trans-unit.source: We will walk through these methods a little later.
trans-unit.target: We will walk through these methods a little later.

trans-unit.source: Next, the index needs to be populated.
trans-unit.target: Next, the index needs to be populated.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we will need a SearchIndexClient.
trans-unit.target: To do this, we will need a SearchIndexClient.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to obtain one: by constructing it, or by calling Indexes.GetClient on the SearchServiceClient.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to obtain one: by constructing it, or by calling Indexes.GetClient on the SearchServiceClient.

trans-unit.source: We use the latter for convenience.
trans-unit.target: We use the latter for convenience.

trans-unit.source: In a typical search application, index management and population is handled by a separate component from search queries.
trans-unit.target: In a typical search application, index management and population is handled by a separate component from search queries.

trans-unit.source: Indexes.GetClient is convenient for populating an index because it saves you the trouble of providing another SearchCredentials.
trans-unit.target: Indexes.GetClient is convenient for populating an index because it saves you the trouble of providing another SearchCredentials.

trans-unit.source: It does this by passing the admin key that you used to create the SearchServiceClient to the new SearchIndexClient.
trans-unit.target: It does this by passing the admin key that you used to create the SearchServiceClient to the new SearchIndexClient.

trans-unit.source: However, in the part of your application that executes queries, it is better to create the SearchIndexClient directly so that you can pass in a query key instead of an admin key.
trans-unit.target: However, in the part of your application that executes queries, it is better to create the SearchIndexClient directly so that you can pass in a query key instead of an admin key.

trans-unit.source: This is consistent with the principle of least privilege and will help to make your application more secure.
trans-unit.target: This is consistent with the principle of least privilege and will help to make your application more secure.

trans-unit.source: You can find out more about admin keys and query keys <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find out more about admin keys and query keys <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Now that we have a SearchIndexClient, we can populate the index.
trans-unit.target: Now that we have a SearchIndexClient, we can populate the index.

trans-unit.source: This is done by another method that we will walk through later.
trans-unit.target: This is done by another method that we will walk through later.

trans-unit.source: Finally, we execute a few search queries and display the results, again using the SearchIndexClient:
trans-unit.target: Finally, we execute a few search queries and display the results, again using the SearchIndexClient:

trans-unit.source: If you run this application with a valid service name and API key, the output should look like this:
trans-unit.target: If you run this application with a valid service name and API key, the output should look like this:

trans-unit.source: The full source code of the application is provided at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: The full source code of the application is provided at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: Next, we will take a closer look at each of the methods called by Main.
trans-unit.target: Next, we will take a closer look at each of the methods called by Main.

trans-unit.source: Creating an Index
trans-unit.target: Creating an Index

trans-unit.source: After creating a SearchServiceClient, the next thing Main does is delete the "hotels" index if it already exists.
trans-unit.target: After creating a SearchServiceClient, the next thing Main does is delete the "hotels" index if it already exists.

trans-unit.source: That is done by the following method:
trans-unit.target: That is done by the following method:

trans-unit.source: This method uses the given SearchServiceClient to check if the index exists, and if so, delete it.
trans-unit.target: This method uses the given SearchServiceClient to check if the index exists, and if so, delete it.

trans-unit.source: The example code in this article uses the synchronous methods of the Azure Search .NET SDK for simplicity.
trans-unit.target: The example code in this article uses the synchronous methods of the Azure Search .NET SDK for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you use the asynchronous methods in your own applications to keep them scalable and responsive.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you use the asynchronous methods in your own applications to keep them scalable and responsive.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the method above you could use ExistsAsync and DeleteAsync instead of Exists and Delete.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the method above you could use ExistsAsync and DeleteAsync instead of Exists and Delete.

trans-unit.source: Next, Main creates a new "hotels" index by calling this method:
trans-unit.target: Next, Main creates a new "hotels" index by calling this method:

trans-unit.source: This method creates a new Index object with a list of Field objects that defines the schema of the new index.
trans-unit.target: This method creates a new Index object with a list of Field objects that defines the schema of the new index.

trans-unit.source: Each field has a name, data type, and several attributes that define its search behavior.
trans-unit.target: Each field has a name, data type, and several attributes that define its search behavior.

trans-unit.source: In addition to fields, you can also add scoring profiles, suggesters, or CORS options to the Index (these are omitted from the sample for brevity).
trans-unit.target: In addition to fields, you can also add scoring profiles, suggesters, or CORS options to the Index (these are omitted from the sample for brevity).

trans-unit.source: You can find more information about the Index object and its constituent parts in the SDK reference on <link><linkText>MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>, as well as in the <link><linkText>Azure Search REST API reference</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find more information about the Index object and its constituent parts in the SDK reference on <link><linkText>MSDN</linkText><title></title></link>, as well as in the <link><linkText>Azure Search REST API reference</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Populating the Index
trans-unit.target: Populating the Index

trans-unit.source: The next step in Main is to populate the newly-created index.
trans-unit.target: The next step in Main is to populate the newly-created index.

trans-unit.source: This is done in the following method:
trans-unit.target: This is done in the following method:

trans-unit.source: This method has four parts.
trans-unit.target: This method has four parts.

trans-unit.source: The first creates an array of Hotel objects that will serve as our input data to upload to the index.
trans-unit.target: The first creates an array of Hotel objects that will serve as our input data to upload to the index.

trans-unit.source: This data is hard-coded for simplicity.
trans-unit.target: This data is hard-coded for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: In your own application, your data will likely come from an external data source such as a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In your own application, your data will likely come from an external data source such as a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The second part creates an IndexAction for each Hotel, then groups those together in a new IndexBatch.
trans-unit.target: The second part creates an IndexAction for each Hotel, then groups those together in a new IndexBatch.

trans-unit.source: The batch is then uploaded to the Azure Search index by the Documents.Index method.
trans-unit.target: The batch is then uploaded to the Azure Search index by the Documents.Index method.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we are just uploading documents.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we are just uploading documents.

trans-unit.source: If you wanted to merge changes into an existing document or a delete a document, you could create an IndexAction with the corresponding IndexActionType.
trans-unit.target: If you wanted to merge changes into an existing document or a delete a document, you could create an IndexAction with the corresponding IndexActionType.

trans-unit.source: We don't need to specify IndexActionType in this example because the default is Upload.
trans-unit.target: We don't need to specify IndexActionType in this example because the default is Upload.

trans-unit.source: The third part of this method is a catch block that handles an important error case for indexing.
trans-unit.target: The third part of this method is a catch block that handles an important error case for indexing.

trans-unit.source: If your Azure Search service fails to index some of the documents in the batch, an IndexBatchException is thrown by Documents.Index.
trans-unit.target: If your Azure Search service fails to index some of the documents in the batch, an IndexBatchException is thrown by Documents.Index.

trans-unit.source: This can happen if you are indexing documents while your service is under heavy load.
trans-unit.target: This can happen if you are indexing documents while your service is under heavy load.

trans-unit.source: We strongly recommend explicitly handling this case in your code. You can delay and then retry indexing the documents that failed, or you can log and continue like the sample does, or you can do something else depending on your application's data consistency requirements.
trans-unit.target: We strongly recommend explicitly handling this case in your code. You can delay and then retry indexing the documents that failed, or you can log and continue like the sample does, or you can do something else depending on your application's data consistency requirements.

trans-unit.source: Finally, the method delays for two seconds.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the method delays for two seconds.

trans-unit.source: Indexing happens asynchronously in your Azure Search service, so the sample application needs to wait a short time to ensure that the documents are available for searching.
trans-unit.target: Indexing happens asynchronously in your Azure Search service, so the sample application needs to wait a short time to ensure that the documents are available for searching.

trans-unit.source: Delays like this are typically only necessary in demos, tests, and sample applications.
trans-unit.target: Delays like this are typically only necessary in demos, tests, and sample applications.

trans-unit.source: How the .NET SDK Handles Documents
trans-unit.target: How the .NET SDK Handles Documents

trans-unit.source: You may be wondering how the Azure Search .NET SDK is able to upload instances of a user-defined class like Hotel to the index.
trans-unit.target: You may be wondering how the Azure Search .NET SDK is able to upload instances of a user-defined class like Hotel to the index.

trans-unit.source: To help answer that question, let's look at the Hotel class:
trans-unit.target: To help answer that question, let's look at the Hotel class:

trans-unit.source: The first thing to notice is that each public property of Hotel corresponds to a field in the index definition, but with one crucial difference: The name of each field starts with a lower-case letter ("camel case"), while the name of each public property of Hotel starts with an upper-case letter ("Pascal case").
trans-unit.target: The first thing to notice is that each public property of Hotel corresponds to a field in the index definition, but with one crucial difference: The name of each field starts with a lower-case letter ("camel case"), while the name of each public property of Hotel starts with an upper-case letter ("Pascal case").

trans-unit.source: This is a common scenario in .NET applications that perform data-binding where the target schema is outside the control of the application developer.
trans-unit.target: This is a common scenario in .NET applications that perform data-binding where the target schema is outside the control of the application developer.

trans-unit.source: Rather than having to violate the .NET naming guidelines by making property names camel-case, you can tell the SDK to map the property names to camel-case automatically with the [SerializePropertyNamesAsCamelCase] attribute.
trans-unit.target: Rather than having to violate the .NET naming guidelines by making property names camel-case, you can tell the SDK to map the property names to camel-case automatically with the [SerializePropertyNamesAsCamelCase] attribute.

trans-unit.source: The second important thing about the Hotel class are the data types of the public properties.
trans-unit.target: The second important thing about the Hotel class are the data types of the public properties.

trans-unit.source: The .NET types of these properties map to their equivalent field types in the index definition.
trans-unit.target: The .NET types of these properties map to their equivalent field types in the index definition.

trans-unit.source: For example, the Category string property maps to the category field, which is of type Edm.String.
trans-unit.target: For example, the Category string property maps to the category field, which is of type Edm.String.

trans-unit.source: There are similar type mappings between bool? and Edm.Boolean, DateTimeOffset? and Edm.DateTimeOffset, etc.
trans-unit.target: There are similar type mappings between bool? and Edm.Boolean, DateTimeOffset? and Edm.DateTimeOffset, etc.

trans-unit.source: The specific rules for the type mapping are documented with the Documents.Get method on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: The specific rules for the type mapping are documented with the Documents.Get method on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Note that value types such as bool and int are nullable in the Hotel class because all primitive field types in Azure Search are nullable.
trans-unit.target: Note that value types such as bool and int are nullable in the Hotel class because all primitive field types in Azure Search are nullable.

trans-unit.source: This ability to use your own classes as documents works in both directions; You can also retrieve search results and have the SDK automatically deserialize them to a type of your choice, as we will see in the next section.
trans-unit.target: This ability to use your own classes as documents works in both directions; You can also retrieve search results and have the SDK automatically deserialize them to a type of your choice, as we will see in the next section.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search .NET SDK also supports dynamically-typed documents using the Document class, which is a key/value mapping of field names to field values.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search .NET SDK also supports dynamically-typed documents using the Document class, which is a key/value mapping of field names to field values.

trans-unit.source: This is useful in scenarios where you don't know the index schema at design-time, or where it would be inconvenient to bind to specific model classes.
trans-unit.target: This is useful in scenarios where you don't know the index schema at design-time, or where it would be inconvenient to bind to specific model classes.

trans-unit.source: All the methods in the SDK that deal with documents have overloads that work with the Document class, as well as strongly-typed overloads that take a generic type parameter.
trans-unit.target: All the methods in the SDK that deal with documents have overloads that work with the Document class, as well as strongly-typed overloads that take a generic type parameter.

trans-unit.source: Only the latter are used in the sample code in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Only the latter are used in the sample code in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You can find out more about the Document class here.
trans-unit.target: You can find out more about the Document class here.

trans-unit.source: Searching for Documents in the Index
trans-unit.target: Searching for Documents in the Index

trans-unit.source: The last step in the sample application is to search for some documents in the index.
trans-unit.target: The last step in the sample application is to search for some documents in the index.

trans-unit.source: The following method does this:
trans-unit.target: The following method does this:

trans-unit.source: First, this method creates a new SearchParameters object.
trans-unit.target: First, this method creates a new SearchParameters object.

trans-unit.source: This is used to specify additional options for the query such as sorting, filtering, paging, and faceting.
trans-unit.target: This is used to specify additional options for the query such as sorting, filtering, paging, and faceting.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we're only setting the Filter property.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we're only setting the Filter property.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to actually execute the search query.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to actually execute the search query.

trans-unit.source: This is done using the Documents.Search method.
trans-unit.target: This is done using the Documents.Search method.

trans-unit.source: In this case, we pass the search text to use as a string, plus the search parameters created earlier.
trans-unit.target: In this case, we pass the search text to use as a string, plus the search parameters created earlier.

trans-unit.source: We also specify Hotel as the type parameter for Documents.Search, which tells the SDK to deserialize documents in the search results into objects of type Hotel.
trans-unit.target: We also specify Hotel as the type parameter for Documents.Search, which tells the SDK to deserialize documents in the search results into objects of type Hotel.

trans-unit.source: Finally, this method iterates through all the matches in the search results, printing each document to the console.
trans-unit.target: Finally, this method iterates through all the matches in the search results, printing each document to the console.

trans-unit.source: Let's take a closer look at how this method is called:
trans-unit.target: Let's take a closer look at how this method is called:

trans-unit.source: In the first call, we're looking for all documents containing the query terms "fancy" or "wifi".
trans-unit.target: In the first call, we're looking for all documents containing the query terms "fancy" or "wifi".

trans-unit.source: In the second call, the search text is set to "*", which means "find everything".
trans-unit.target: In the second call, the search text is set to "*", which means "find everything".

trans-unit.source: You can find more information about the search query expression syntax <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find more information about the search query expression syntax <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The second call uses an OData $filter expression, category eq 'Luxury'.
trans-unit.target: The second call uses an OData $filter expression, category eq 'Luxury'.

trans-unit.source: This constrains the search to only return documents where the category field exactly matches the string "Luxury".
trans-unit.target: This constrains the search to only return documents where the category field exactly matches the string "Luxury".

trans-unit.source: You can find out more about the OData syntax that Azure Search supports <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find out more about the OData syntax that Azure Search supports <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Now that you know what these two calls do, it should be easier to see why their output looks like this:
trans-unit.target: Now that you know what these two calls do, it should be easier to see why their output looks like this:

trans-unit.source: The first search returns two documents.
trans-unit.target: The first search returns two documents.

trans-unit.source: The first has "Fancy" in the name, while the second has "wifi" in the tags field.
trans-unit.target: The first has "Fancy" in the name, while the second has "wifi" in the tags field.

trans-unit.source: The second search returns two documents, which happen to be the only documents in the index that have the category field set to "Luxury".
trans-unit.target: The second search returns two documents, which happen to be the only documents in the index that have the category field set to "Luxury".

trans-unit.source: This step completes the tutorial, but don't stop here.
trans-unit.target: This step completes the tutorial, but don't stop here.

trans-unit.source: Next steps provides additional resources for learning more about Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: Next steps provides additional resources for learning more about Azure Search.

trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.target: Read about features and capabilities in this version of the Azure Search SDK: <link><linkText>Azure Search Overview</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: Review <link><linkText>naming conventions</linkText><title></title></link> to learn the rules for naming various objects.

trans-unit.target: Review <link><linkText>supported data types</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: Sample Application Source Code
trans-unit.target: Sample Application Source Code
